titleStmt.title: M51. Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. correction on p. 3, unsigned and undated. 9p. Wanting p. 1. Paginated 2-10
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M51. Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. correction on p. 3, unsigned and undated. 9p. Wanting p. 1. Paginated 2-10

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
2
Anon.

common voice singing out of doors. he has no house. He lives
a roaming life, crossing the fields, mounting (moutning) the hills,
and lying down by the hawthown to listen to the (te) nightingale.

Still, by shutting out a chimney (chimey) or a bungalow
we can see what saw-- the bird haunted reed whispering
fen, the down, and the green scar never healed along which
he came when he made his journeys. He was a simple (simp le) singer,
lifting a song or a story from other peoples lips, and letting (lettig)
the audience (auience) join in the chorus (chours). Sometimes he made a few
lines that exactly matched his (matchedhis) emotion (emtoin)--he was an artist (arist).
But there is no name to that song.

When at last the house was built, he sung (song) only at the
back door. Upstairs they spoke French; his song was sung
in English; and the words were so uncouth

Icham for woing al forwake
Wery no water in wore
that they need (n ed) a dictionary (ditioc nary) now.]

Icham for woing al forwake
Wery no water in wore

But (Bu ) to the listener then, to for example ( xample) in his
parsonage (pasronage), they were not only difficult. They were painful.
They reminded him of his lack of intellectual [illeg.]
His intellectual pedigree reached back (vack) only to
, , a bare hundred (hundre) and fifty years.
To have ancestors (anscestors) he must cross (ross) the . His ancestors
by way of the mind are Greeks and Romans (Rla ns). His page is

burdened (bu dened) with protestations (protesttaions) of (og) good breeding--
; , ; --xxxxxxx
ixx quotes them to prove his good breeding as we to prove
ours quote the Elizabethans (Elizabthans).

was not a respectable (respecable) ancestor. He was nameless
because he was disreputable (disrputable). Even the Kings and Queens must
have their singers (sin ers), their minstrels (mistrels), their xxxxxxx actors.
But he was despised. Did he not feeling himself an outcast,
use the outsiders privilege of irresponsible (irreponsible) mockery?
Hewas tolerated, as we tolerate those who say out loud
what we think, but will not admit. So he sang, danced
juggled ( uggled) and led his bears to the back door (doot). He sings to
serving men and maids. He tells them what they have heard
already (aldready)--old stories in in those ( inm hose) choruses they can join.
When the great Elizabethan house was built, he was still
nameless, disreputable (disreptuable), the parson (prason) of
in instead of setting down those songs (ongs), digs up
coins. He already sees (s s) the present against the past.
The past has become so settled that the (yhe) present looks
ungainly ( ngainly) and degenerate (d g n rate) against it. There is too much
comfort, too many pillows (pi ows), too many chimneys. The young
and are not the men their fathers were.
The smoke (msmoke) drawn up by the chimneys (chimeys) no longer (lo ger) hardens them.
They are tender and subject to rheumatism. They dress
fantastically (fantatically) compared with their ancestors. (ancestor.s) It does not
occur to him to set down the songs that were being sung, to
describe the pageants, (pagentatns ,) the mumming (mu ming), the plays that the
wandering minstrels (mistrels) enacted. The English past served only to
show the material change-- the change that (tha) had come over

houses, furniture (furinture) clothing (clothing½) There was no English literature
to show up the change in the mind. There were no English
books (boo s) to show up the decline of English writing.

Up stairs in the great room, as Harrison (Ha ison) tells us,
"...our ancient ladies of the court (co rt)" were (we e) to be found reading
the Greeks (Gekks) and Latins as they sat at their needlework (needlwork).
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx Greek and Latin
came as easily to their pens as English. At
instance (isnatnec) sat writing to her son. Her letters
might have been sermons from the pulpit. Shxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx She exhorted (exhorst); she admonished (admonsihed).
Fear of God, suspicion (suspcion) of man surround her with the walls
of a dungeon. There is no gaiety, no familiarity, no intimacy
in this world. She ( hw) drapes (draoes) herself in the language (langauge) of the Bible (B le)
when she writes; and it is a garment only to fit a certain
attitude. Save for and and the voice of
singing at the back door, making his irreverent (irrevent) mockeries
xmxmxmxmxmx the English might be a dumb race; a race of
merchants soldiers (soliders) priests, who left behind ( ehind) them stone houses
cultivated fields and many churches, but no words. The
great house is silent (sielnt). We can see it still, standing (satnding) in its
green island of park, separated (seaparated) often from the high road,
only by a dip in the ground and a low red wall. It is out
of proportion (porpotion) now; either (iether) it is too large or the
village with its bungalows (bungalwos) and shops is too small. The furniture (furn)
is in existence (exsitnce) too. Inside all is kept as if the Queen were
expected. The up right Elizabethan chairs stand round the
walls. Their fringes and their tapestry (tap st y) is not much faded
The oak tables are heavy and polished. The floor is strewn (str wn)

The oak tables are heavy and polished. The floor is
laid with rugs; cut glass chandeliers (chand liers) hang down from the
decorated plaster work of the ceiling (celing). Knick knacks (Kick kncaks) have survived (survid)
an inlaid work box, an old doublet; and the pear shaped
lute that the once played.

But if (of) the great Elizabethan (Elizabethna) house looks to us out of
proportion, a derelict among the bungalows, it is because (b cause)
the connection between it and the village is lost. If we
could see the great house as it was in time we
should see tracks raying out from the great house across the
fields to the cottage, to the farm, even to the hovel.
Paths were worn by the fighters; and the ploughers.
They must be armed against other men. They must
plough and sow together if they were not to starve in winter
This connection between (isbetween) master and man is painfully (pa nfully)
minutely recorded (minutelt recoredc) in the medieval letters. It is (I Its is) the staple (stape)
of the (th) whole correspondence between of and the
and the of . But there was also the other
less visible (visibl) connection--the common belief. That
bond between the houses has been grown (gorwn) over, lies (li e) the track
along which the rode to .
Nobody rides there now. But when made his (is)
that track led from house to house. It led to the
village green; it led to the tree; to the well (welll). In the
spring they danced round the maypole; in at midsummer they
lit (llit) the bon fire on the hill. At christmas the mummers
acted their dumb shows; and the boys came wassailing (wassiling).
The road led to the old Kings graces, to the stones

where the old pagan English had done sacrifice.
The peasants still went that way by instinct, in spring
and summer and winer. The old Gods lay hidden (hideen) beneath the
new. If they were nameless now, it was to them, not to the
Christian God, that the peasants (peants) did homage; wearing their
green leaves to propagate (propittte) the earth Goddess; dancing through
the houses; killing the old; reviving the new.

It is in the twenty one books of the
that we tap into the deep reservoir (resev ir) of common belief that
sunk , in the minds of the nobles and peasants.
It is in pages that we hear the voice of
murmuring (murmurinf) still. Kings and Queens, nobles and peasants (peasnts)
remembered how the old King and his knights went
their ways through the wild woods seeking adventure. When
himself doubted if any such man had ever been,
the gentlemen of England were positive. They said that you
could see skull at ; and the
at ; and "in otherplaces sword and many
other things." Txxxxxxxxxxxxxx In
time a silver (silv r) horse shoe had been found at . The book
comes to at the very moment when the old stories were
fading. It xxxxxxxxx is half fable, half fact.
There is ; and and ; there is the
and . But the roads lead
past London to cast s where Knights lie enchanted;
down the roads ride for Queens on white mules;
turns herself suddenly to stone; and a hand rises from
a lake holding . It is (Itis) a childs story, in the

simplicity of its belief. It is a child's (chi s) story in its
particularity. Beauty is stated, not suggested. So he went
in and searched from chamber to chamber, and found his bed,
but she was not (ot) here; then Balin looked into a little garden,
and under a laurel tree he saw (e sae) her lie upon a quilt of green
samite and a knght with her, and under their heads
grass (grasa) and herbs."

But, save that self consciousness (oncsiousnes) has not yet raised
its mirror, it is not a childs world. The men and women are
corrupt already in this fresh world. They have evil dreams.
is doomed. Great kings ( reat ki gs) are undone by their own vices.
The Queens (Quuens) are lustful. Still we can revisit (revsit) their world.
But of the writer (wr ter) nothing is known. is not distinct
from his book. It is still the voice of , speaking to
the voice of anon. The dream is still dreamt. "...folks
do say" a peasant (peasnt) at said in the nineteenth (ninenenth) century,
"that on the night of the full moon King Arthur and his men
ride round the hill, and their horses are shod with silver..."

, printing the at the solicitation (solitictaion)
of the nobles and the gentry, had his doubts. Anon wxxxx
still existed (existsed) but a shade has fallen upon (upo) him. The printed
book with its writers name attached to was destined to kill
him. After that, the audience became separate from
the singer. And the audience (audeince) no longer took part in the song
supplied (supp ied) the story, filled in the pauses, and added sometimes
a nonsensical chorus. The printed book separated (seapareted) from the
voice and was read by those who could afford to buy them.
The great read them in the great rooms. "I spent most of

my time" wrote playing at Clecko
and hearing read the ... used to
read (r ad) to me in and Moll Neville in the
."

The book must find its way into the hall, into the
great room where nobles (novles) and gentry (genrty) have leisure (liesure) to read
after the business (busniess) and the sport of the day is over.
And with the printed book, the writer at last comes into
existence--the writer wxxxxx who, unlike (unl e) the minstrel (mistrel),
has a name; whose words are printed. He is in being after
1477 but he is still undifferentiated (stillundiffrentiated), limited. For when familiar
letters are written in Biblical prose, only in emergency
there must be a barrier between the sayable and the unsayable
a limit to what can be put into words. The artist-- who
stands outside, by some impulse desiring to observe and to
state rather than to take part, is not wholly writer,
wholly musician or wholly painter. It seems possible that the
great English art may not be (b ) the art of letters. Every ( ry) word
is read aloud; every word is given weight and edge by the
speaking voice. And then the lute, the virginals they (the)
gave lilt, rhythm (rhymn) and melody ot the written word.
When in 1666 the london was burning and the citizens
were loading their goods into boats noted that "hardly
one lighter or boat in three (threee) that had the goods of a
house in it, but there was a pair of virginals in it."

Nevertheless (theless), they could not follow the speaking voice, that
voice that talks briefly, colloquially. The audience is
speechless.

then (the n), standing on the threshold of the
great room at --"a little man with short
hair, a small band and cuffs"--- was separate from Anon the
minstrel (misntrel); separate from Holinshed (Holingshed) the chronicler (chorniclaer); and
separate, in that he saw the scene with detachment and wished
to record it, from (fro ) his audience (audie ce). But the book which had
given his word a separate existence (exsience), had brought into being
a little group of readers. That influence, unknown to Anon,
began at once to exert its pressure. What is the (he) poem that
will please ? What is the theme that will
flatter the ? What will so flatter the audience that
they will procure for the poet a place, a pension?
From this time (tiem) onward these are to be among the influences
that tug, that distort, that thwart (twart); as also they
stimulate, and draw out. There are some among them
that the writer only realises (reaslies); others that the readers
in time to come discover. More and more complex do they (t ey)
grow, as the (t e) book with the authors name on it
reaches (r aches) a more various a more divided audience (audi ce). The the
public insists; it wants, according to its wealth (welah) and its
poverty (poeverty), its education or ignorance (irgnoarnce,), now history (hist ry)
now melodrama (meloframa), now poetry (powtry), now whatever will make it forget
its drab and dismal existence. As the book becomes more and
more aware of these influences (infl unces) the thing that the writer

More and more deflected by these influences (infleunces), the thing that
the writer has to say becomes increasingly cumbered. It is
only to be discovered (dsicover d) in flash intuition (intuiton). Thus some say
that their beards bristle when they come upon it; others
that a thrill runs down the nerves of the thigh. To disengage (disengag)
the song from its encumbrances becomes as time goes on
a task for the critic--that specially (sp cially) equipped taster
who was not in existence when stood on the threshold
of the great room at .
It was still connected with the village.
